About

  • Overview
  • Mission
    • Why Does AIQC Exist?
      • 1. Accelerate science by making deep learning accessible.
      • 2. Bring the scientific method to data science.
      • 3. Break down walled gardens to keep science open.
  • Community
    • Purpose.
    • How can I get involved?

    • Programming style.
    • Code of conduct.
    • Guild bylaws (aka Governance).
    • AIQC, Inc. (open core).

Documentation

  • Visualization & Metrics
    • Prerequisites
    • Overview
    • Classification

  • High-Level API
    • Overview
    • Prerequisites
    • 1. Pipeline
      • a) Tabular Dataset
      • b) Sequence Dataset
      • c) Image Dataset
    • 2. Experiment
      • Model Functions
        • fn_build
        • fn_train
      • Hyperparameters
      • Experiment.make()
  • Low-Level API
    • Prerequisites
    • 1. Ingest a Dataset
      • Object Relational Model (ORM)
      • Persisting and Compressing Structured Data
      • Data Sources
        • Dataset.Tabular.from_pandas()
        • Dataset.Tabular.from_numpy()
        • Dataset.Tabular.from_path
        • Sequence Datasets
        • Dataset.Sequence.from_numpy()
        • Image Datasets
        • Dataset.Image.from_urls()
        • Dataset.Image.from_folder()
      • Reading Datasets
      • Dataset.Tabular.to_pandas()
      • Dataset.Tabular.to_numpy()
      • Dataset.Image.to_pillow()
      • Dataset.Image.to_numpy()
    • 2. Select the Label column(s).
      • ORM
      • Deriving Labels
      • Reading Labels
    • 3. Select the Feature column(s).
      • ORM
      • Specifying Features
      • Reading Features
    • 4. Slice samples with a Splitset.
      • Stratification of continuous labels.
      • Split Strategies
        • a) Default supervised 70-30 split.
        • b) Specifying test size.
        • c) Specifying validation size.
      • Reading Splitsets
    • 5. Optionally, create a Foldset for cross-validation.
      • ORM
        • Fold objects
      • Specifying Foldsets
      • Reading Foldsets
        • Sample indices of each Fold:
    • 6. Optionally, encode labels with Labelcoder.
      • Encoding
      • Labelcoder
      • Creating a Labelcoder
    • 7. Optionally, encode Features sequentially with Featurecoder(s).
      • Background
      • Filtering feature columns
      • Creating an Encoderset and attaching multiple Featurecoders to it.
    • 8. Create an Algorithm aka model.
      • ORM
      • Model Definition
        • Function to build model
        • Optional, function to calculate loss.
        • Optional, function to optimize model.
        • Function to train model
        • Optional, function to predict samples
        • Group the functions together in an Algorithm!
    • 9. Optional, associate a Hyperparamset with your model.
      • Parameters are fed into Algorithm functions.
      • Hyperparameter Selection Strategies.
        • Grid search strategy.
        • Random selection strategy.
        • Bayesian selection strategy.
      • Hyperparamcombo objects.
    • 10. Create a Queue of training Jobs.
      • Job objects.
      • Execute all Jobs.
        • 1. queue.run_jobs(in_background=False)
        • 2. queue.run_jobs(in_background=True); experimental
        • 3. Future, distributed cloud execution.
    • 11. Preprocessing during Job is recorded
    • 12. Predictors are the trained models.
      • Fetching the trained model.
    • 13. Predictions are the output of a Predictor.
      • Fetching metrics.
    • 13. Metrics & Visualization
  • Inference
    • Predictor
    • New Splitset
    • Run Inference
  • Compatibility
    • Libraries & Analyses
    • Data Preparation
      • Legend

import numpy as np

[2]:

arr = [
    [1.1, 2.2, 3.3],
    [1.1, 2.2, 3.3],
    [1.1, 2.2, 3.3],
]

[3]:

arr = np.array(arr)

[4]:

arr

[4]:

array([[1.1, 2.2, 3.3],
       [1.1, 2.2, 3.3],
       [1.1, 2.2, 3.3]])

[5]:

arr / 1

[5]:

array([[1.1, 2.2, 3.3],
       [1.1, 2.2, 3.3],
       [1.1, 2.2, 3.3]])

[6]:

arr / 0.5

[6]:

array([[2.2, 4.4, 6.6],
       [2.2, 4.4, 6.6],
       [2.2, 4.4, 6.6]])
